PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  A project preparatory technical assistance is required to (i) assess technical alternatives 
to  ensure  selected  investments  are  least  cost,  (ii)  prepare  feasibility  studies  for  selected 
investments, (iii) conduct due diligence on the proposed project, (iv) undertake capacity building 
analysis,  (v)  assess  options  for  involvement  of  private  sector,  including  IPP  investment, 
operation and maintenance contracts, and (vi) familiarize the implementing agency with ADB’s 
procurement procedures, disbursement procedures, and safeguard requirements.  
B.  Major Outputs and Activities

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The  technical  assistance  is  estimated  to  cost  $750,000  equivalent,  which  will  be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund. The Government will 
finance counterpart staff, office supplies, secretarial assistance, provision of office space, and 
communication facilities for consultants. The technical assistance will commence 26 April 2013 
and will be completed on 3 June 2014. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The  technical  assistance  will  require  7  international  consultants (19 months)  and  3 
national consultants (13 months) to be hired through a consulting firm. Consultants will be 
engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The consulting firm will be engaged through quality and cost based 
selection  method  (quality-cost  ratio  of  90:10)13 using  simplified  technical  proposal.  The 
procurement of equipment by consultants under the  technical assistance will follow ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of the technical 
assistance will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The equipment procured under the technical assistance 
will be turned over to the Government upon technical assistance completion.  
                                                
13 90:10 is considered suitable as the project requires specific technical capacities for design of small hydropower in 
remote island locations.

5.  Team  Leader  (international,  3  person-months  [pm]).  The  team  leader  will  have  a 
minimum  of  15  years  experience  in  design  and  implementation  of  hydropower  projects, 
including  in  developing  countries.  The  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  managing  the 
Consultant team and coordinating the overall PPTA implementation as well as all reporting 
activities, and liaison with stakeholders. The team leader will also be either the transmission and 
distribution engineer or the civil engineer (hydropower) and will be supported by the national 
power sector specialist (4 person-months). The team leader will (i) review background data, (ii) 
confirm power demand forecasts, (iii) carry out least cost power sector planning, (iv) assess 
levelized cost of generation, (v) implement a consultation and participation plan, (vi) liaise with 
stakeholders,  (vii)  prepare  the  detailed  work  program  and  implementation  schedule,  (viii) 
coordinate preparation of the deliverables, including Feasibility Studies, (ix) assess affordability 
issues, (x) prepare the design and monitoring framework (DMF), (xi) undertake a procurement 
capacity  assessment,  (xii)  prepare  a  procurement  plan,  (xiii)  prepare  the  implementation 
schedule,  (xiv)  prepare  terms  of  reference  for  detailed  design  consultants,  (xv)  develop 
performance  indicators,  and  (xvi)  assess  options  for  operation  and  maintenance  of  the 
hydropower assets and if required, design revisions to concession agreements and manage the 
consultation process for concession revisions. 
6.  Transmission and Distribution engineer (international, 3 pm), will have a minimum of 
10 years experience in design and implementation of transmission and distribution projects, 
including  in  developing  countries.  The  engineer  will  (i)  determine  appropriate  transmission 
voltages;  (ii)  determine  routings/easements  for  power  lines;  (iii)  design  transmission  and 
distribution system; (iv) prepare cost estimates for transmission/distribution; and (v) prepare 
construction schedule, and assess technical and non-technical losses and identify solutions for 
addressing any high losses.     
7.  Electro-mechanical engineer (hydropower) (international, 1 pm). The engineer will 
have  a  minimum  of  10  years  demonstrated  experience  in  design  and  implementation  of 
hydropower projects, including in developing countries. The engineer will conduct the following 
for two hydropower sites: (i) determine required capacities in cooperation with the Financial 
specialist,  (ii)  prepare  preliminary  design  for  electromechanical  components  of  the  plants 
including plant regulation and control (iii) optimize designs in cooperation with hydrologist, (iv) 
determine  sequencing  of  installations,  (v)  analyze  required  diesel  back-up  for  hydropower 
plants, and (vi) prepare cost estimates for all electromechanical components.

12  Appendix 4 
8.  Civil Engineer (hydropower) (international, 3 pm). The specialist will have a minimum 
of 10 years demonstrated experience in design and implementation of hydropower projects, 
including in developing countries. The civil engineer (hydropower) will (i) determine scope of 
survey packages; (ii) develop preliminary routings for access roads and canals; (iii) develop 
preliminary designs for intakes, canals, sand traps fore bays, penstocks and powerhouses; (iv) 
prepare cost estimates for all civil engineering components of the plants; (v) source construction 
materials; and (vi) develop construction schedules. The civil engineer (hydropower) will also (i) 
review hydrological studies performed in Vanuatu, (ii) analyze hydrological data collected for the 
two sites, (iii) undertake hydrological analysis suitable for design of the two hydropower plants, 
and (iv) perform an assessment of hydrological risks including flooding during construction and 
operation.  
9.  Financial/Economic  Specialist  (international,  2  pm).  The  specialist  will  have  a 
minimum  of  10  years experience  and  will  be  experienced  in  ADB financial  and  economic 
analysis procedures. The specialist will (i) review financial analysis and update where required, 
including calculation of the financial internal rate of return and weighted average cost of capital; 
(ii) identify project revenue and commercial risks, conduct relevant sensitivity analyses; (iii) 
prepare a financing plan; (iv) review audited financial statements; (v) prepare projected financial 
statements  for  the  IA  for  10  years,  including  a  sensitivity  analysis;  (vi)  complete  relevant 
sections  of  the  RRP,  including  COSTAB  tables;  (vii)  review  tariffs;  (viii)  conduct  financial 
management assessment; and (ix) carry out an economic analysis (including demand analysis, 
least-cost analysis, economic viability analysis, economic internal rate of return), and derive 
electricity demand functions for the domestic and non-domestic consumer classes on which the 
valuation of incremental output can be valued.    
10.  Environment  Specialists  (international  2  pm,  national  3  pm)  will  have  10  years 
experience  in  environmental  assessment  of  infrastructure  projects,  preferably  in the  power 
sector  and  will  (i)  prepare  environmental  assessment,  (ii)  consult  with  stakeholders,  (iii) 
incorporate mitigation measures, (iv) quantify environmental costs and benefits and valued for 
input  into  the  least  cost  analysis  and  EIRR  calculation,  (v)  develop  grievance  redress 
mechanism, (vi) manage surveys, (vii) assess climate and disaster-related risks, (viii) estimate 
CO  emission reductions, and (ix) prepare an initial environmental examination.

11.  Private Sector Development Specialist (international, 1 pm). The specialist will have a 
minimum of 10 years experience in designing private sector options for infrastructure investment 
in developing countries. The specialist will (i) review literature; (ii) consult with investors; (iii) 
assess policy and regulatory barriers; (iv) assess potential for IPPs in power generation; (v) 
identify the most feasible private sector models for development of hydropower; (vi) identify 
local contractors; and (vii) assess external operation and maintenance contracts, and assess 
options for operation and maintenance of the hydropower assets, including integration into 
existing concession agreements or engagement of separate private sector contractors.    
12.  Social Safeguard/Resettlement Specialists (international 4 pm, national 6 pm). The 
specialists will (i) collect background data, (ii) conduct surveys, (iii) implement a stakeholder and 
community consultation plan, (iv) assess the pro-poor impacts, (v) assess the gender impact 
and  prepare gender  action  plan,  (vi)  prepare Poverty  and  Social  Assessments (PSA)  and 
Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (SPRSS), (vii) assess vulnerabilities and risks 
associated with HIV/AIDS and other health impacts, and (viii) prepare socioeconomic monitoring 
and management plans. The specialists will undertake due diligence/assessment on involuntary 
resettlement and indigenous peoples. For land acquisition/resettlement, the specialists will: (i)

review the country systems and identify any gaps; (ii) assess land acquisition/resettlement 
impacts; and (iii) develop resettlement plan. Prepare an indigenous peoples plan if required.  
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The executing agency will be the Department of Energy, Mines and Mineral Resources 
(DEMMR). A Program Management Unit (PMU) will be established within DEMMR and will be 
supported  by  implementation  consultants.  The  EA  will  provide  support  to  the  consultants, 
including (i) arranging meetings with relevant Government stakeholders, (ii) providing access to 
all  relevant  data,  and  (iii)  a  suitably  furnished  office  with  utilities  and  telecommunications 
access.
